data.text: Things You Should Know Before Getting into Bikepacking
What are some things you wish you knew before getting into bikepacking?
That many of the people who have opinions and offer advice about bikepacking have no practical experience and only repeat what they see on the Internet.
data.author: Kevin Lee

data.text: Leave 75% of what you pack at home üòÇ First trip I had like 50lbs, a trailer, handlebar bag. By the end of the first week crossing the country I had ditched 35lbs, the trailer and handlebar bag.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: A book on traveling I got when I was 17 called Europe through the Bcak Dior said "lay put everything tou want to take with you on your bed. Now, put half back! " Mind blowing stuff to me at the time. 35 years later, I am still doing that.
data.author: TC Rboert Dawson

data.text: I wish I didn't listen to people on social media! Do not fall into buying all the expensive stuff they recommend!
data.author: Edina Niksz

data.text: or maybe ask why that product is being recommended. Sometimes the bargains are the expensive items.
data.author: David Muise

data.text: You can start with cheaper alternatives or whatever you already have . You need to figure it out what works for you . I almost bought a very expensive down sleeping bag because everyone said I will need one . Because it's light weight , pack small etc. Finally I went to Walmart and got the cheapest $30 synthetic sleeping bag. 7000km and I'm still using it !
data.author: Edina Niksz

data.text: Free internet, free electricity, book exchanges, bathrooms, heating and AC, computers, borrow tools... Cities have become places with nothing public except parks, streets, and libraries. The countryside has become private/farmland. Stores and storefronts near me have been removing tables and outlets because of all the homeless problems. Guess all this just make me appreciate a place I can get out of the elements for a moment.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: DT 350 hubs are known for being very reliable, a good value and they have good engagement so I wouldn‚Äôt call them ordinary but a trustworthy option. That said, the reason I mentioned them in this context is because you can remove the entire freehub by hand with the cassette still on if you ever need to change a spoke thanks to their star rachet design.

data.author: Andrew Besold

data.author: James Folsom

data.text: Its not a race, take it slow
data.author: Jay Rapson

data.text: Keep dry in colder weather
data.author: Simon Hodson

data.text: You don't necessarily need a fancy bike, or all the latest and greatest bags and gear, although of course that is nice. You can do it with whatever bike you have and whatever bags you can cobble together, even if it is a small backpack. Just pack light and do a small trip. Sure, it won't get you round the world, but tou don't have to go round the world for your first trip. Just do it, with whatever you have, enjoy the experience and learn what works for you, not what works for me or people on facebook. Oh, most important, talk to people on the way, you will hear some amazing stuff and learn a lot, and be humbled and amazed by the kindness and curiosity of strangers
data.author: Andrew Robinson

data.text: That after a your first tour, normal life is even more tiresomeüòÇ
data.author: Angela Hart

data.text: Never bikepacked but did 87 tours with panniers and handlebar bag and sometimes a big saddlebag as well. Some of my advice will pertain to bikepacking as well. 1. Always have some emergency food. A couple of tins of fish is ideal as it keeps and has protein. You MUST have protein in emergency food. 2. Never forget suncream. 3. If you put on damp shorts or a damp first layer, it'll be dry in ten minutes. 4. If you wash clothes in a hotel bedroom etc., squeeze out the water, then lay them on a towel. Swissroll the lot and walk barefoot along the towel. That'll have them as dry as you can physically get them, and hang them up. They're usually dry in the morning. 5. Two Panadol (paracetamol, acetaminophen) just before sleep will give you a better sleep as slight muscle soreness tends to disturb it. 6. The most memorable things from a tour include talking to ordinary people, having a look into a church etc., taking photos etc. A camera is better than a phone as selfies are a load of rubbish vs a shot taken with a self-timer. 7. If one side of your backside gets persistently sore, turn the nose of your saddle slightly to that side and see if it helps. It really did for me. 8. After 30y of cleats I got rid of them due to a torn meniscus and persistent knee pain. The real cure is flat pedals with stiffish soled shoes AND putting the pedal axle under mid-sole rather than forefoot. I'm three years without pain after doing this. You lose NO power. 9. Carry a bit of canvas which you can put inside a smallish tear in the side of a tyre. Called a boot. Won't work if the tear is on the part of the tyre which is on the road. A little bit of glue, or solution will hold it in place. 10. For commonly accessed allen keys, proper keys are much less fiddly than those on a multitool. 11. Carry a few links of spare chain AND a chaintool. Also maybe 4 spare spokes for rear wheel, two from each side. 12. Take it easy. Effortless pedalling will still make you tired. In my early days of touring I used a pulsemeter and had a max pulse beyond which I would not go. 13. How to climb a big hill. Head off at what seems a modest pace and slow down after 100 yards/metres. 14. A 5 minute break is very refreshing. 15. To eat carbs only, as on the bike food, is a mistake. You'll get the knock/bonk easier. Eat a cheese sandwich with not too much bread. 16. I use two pumps. One short fat one for volume. One slender one for Higher pressure. Combo is excellent.

data.text: Any real or new advice on avoiding bites?
data.author: Beth Sheltrown

data.text: it is really tough specially with the huge number of ticks there are more every day, you have to control yourself if you have any very often but they are really tiny, they like humid green places where there are animals, also fallen tree branches or pine needles, they preffer the shade than the sun and they are more active late afternoon/evening, so, for us the biggest dilema is when camping, wild or campsite, even if you are very carefull during the night they can be attached to the tent and when you pack it up in the morning it can climb on to you, june through september are the worst in northern hemisphere, it is a nightmare to try to control the bites but it is nothing compared with the chronic disease, i hope this helps to avoid it ...
data.author: Tomas Aperlo

data.text: It is helpful. Didn‚Äôt know they dislike sun and are more active in the afternoon. I camp, hike and kayak all the time but have never found a good solution for ticks. üòû (same issue with chiggers)

data.text: That life is so much flatter on an Ebike!!!!
data.author: Clayton Henderson

data.text: The only people that care about how many miles you did (maybe besides yourself) are the people who have never toured before. The people you meet on the road, in the campsite, etc will always have better stories than you and not one of them will care if you've done 10 miles or 10,000. They just want to hear your experience on the road. Talk to everyone, visit sites, stay out of cities, and never care about how many miles you do because it'll never be enough. The number one lesson though -- when it‚Äôs no longer fun, or when it feels right (you'll know) -- then call it a tour and head home. Even if you haven't done everything you wanted to. There is no ego on the road..

data.text: I always tried to lighten my pack thinking the extra weight was making going up hills and mountains too tough. Yes, be smart about what you pack but leave yourself enough to be comfortable when you reach your destination. Often, you will spend more time at camp than you did on the bike. Extra weight might slow you down a little but you will get used to it and glad you have it at the end of the day.
data.author: Curt Melzer

data.text: Brooks saddles are like a leather arm chairs for bikes.

data.text: Baby wipes are important. Clean ur ass and hands with these after using a restroom with "shit finger" toilet paper. Can be used to clean ur body when showers arent available. Also wen u have to work on ur chain u can clean ur hands with them. Clean dishes and gear with them. Wen bikepacking theres only 4 rules to follow. 1. Always have a water filter 2. Always have food/snacks 3. Always have a shelter on u even if u plan to stay at hotels 4. If you havent used a peice of gear in 3 days of bikepacking send it back home or throw it away cuz u didnt need it. U will save a lot of weight this way u need less than wat u think. U dont need so many power banks cuz ur gonna be riding and u can usually recharge ur stuff at a store like walmart. Deer dont know ur there wen ur tent camping had several walk into my tent at night like literally trip over my tent.
data.author: Richard Tydryszewski

data.text: Don't think too much. Don't plan, don't ask stupid questions on Facebook. Don't spent money on fancy gear/bike. Just go.
data.author: Piotr Waksmundzki
